text: He sent darkness, and made it dark; and they rebelled not against his word.
text_kjv: He sent darkness, and made it dark; and they rebelled not against his word.
text_niv: He sent darkness and made the land dark—for had they not rebelled against his words?
text_esv: He sent darkness, and made the land dark; they did not rebel  against his words.
text_nlt: The LORD blanketed Egypt in darkness,for they had defied his commands to let his people go.
text_msg: He spoke, "Darkness!" and it turned dark—they couldn't see what they were doing.
text_nasb: He sent darkness and made [it] dark; And they did not rebel against His words.
context: Psalm 105 is a historical psalm, recounting God's faithfulness to Israel from the time of Abraham through the Exodus. Verse 28 refers specifically to the ninth plague God inflicted upon Egypt, described in Exodus 10:21-29. The context of the plagues is crucial. Pharaoh repeatedly refused to release the Israelites, despite witnessing increasingly devastating displays of God's power. Each plague targeted a specific Egyptian deity or aspect of Egyptian life, demonstrating God's sovereignty and challenging the Egyptian worldview. The darkness was not merely a physical inconvenience; it was a direct assault on Ra, the Egyptian sun god, a principal deity believed to be the source of light and life. The phrase 'they rebelled not against his word' emphasizes the obedience of the natural world (in this case, darkness) to God's command, in stark contrast to Pharaoh's defiant disobedience. Understanding the societal structure of ancient Egypt is also important. Pharaoh was considered a divine ruler, and challenging his authority was akin to challenging the gods themselves. The plagues were, therefore, a direct confrontation with Pharaoh's presumed divinity and the entire Egyptian pantheon. This psalm serves as a reminder of God's power to deliver his people from oppression and to establish his covenant despite human resistance. This event was ingrained in the collective memory of the Israelites, serving as a constant reminder of God's faithfulness and their obligation to him.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 105:28 highlights several key aspects of God's character and actions. First, it underscores God's absolute sovereignty over creation. God commands the darkness, and it obeys. This demonstrates that even forces that seem uncontrollable are subject to his will. The darkness itself becomes an instrument of God's judgment, contrasting sharply with the Egyptian belief in Ra. Secondly, the phrase 'they rebelled not against his word' draws a deliberate contrast between the natural world's obedience and Pharaoh's stubborn refusal to acknowledge God's authority. It suggests a hierarchy of obedience, with creation serving God and humanity ideally mirroring that obedience. This obedience is not mindless conformity but a recognition of God's rightful place as the Creator and sustainer of all things. The darkness also symbolizes God's judgment and the spiritual blindness of those who reject him. Just as the Egyptians were enveloped in physical darkness, they were also blinded to the truth of God's power and his call for justice. This verse points to the consequence of rebellion against God's word, which leads to a state of spiritual darkness and separation from him. It serves as a reminder that choosing to follow God's commands brings light and life, while rejecting them leads to darkness and destruction. Furthermore, the psalm implies that God's word has inherent power. It is not merely a suggestion or a request; it is a decree that carries the force of divine authority. This understanding of God's word as powerful and effective is a cornerstone of Christian theology.
application: Psalm 105:28 offers several practical applications for modern life. First, it calls us to recognize God's sovereignty in all circumstances, even in the 'dark' times of our lives. When facing hardship, illness, or uncertainty, we can remember that God is still in control and can use even difficult situations for his purposes. The 'darkness' in our lives, like the plague in Egypt, can serve as a reminder of our dependence on God and our need to trust in his guidance. Secondly, the verse challenges us to examine our own obedience to God's word. Are we quick to rebel against his commands, or do we strive to align our lives with his will? Just as the darkness obeyed God, we should seek to obey his word in all aspects of our lives – in our relationships, our work, and our thoughts. This requires a conscious effort to study Scripture, pray for guidance, and cultivate a heart that is receptive to God's leading. Thirdly, the verse reminds us of the consequences of rejecting God's word. Just as the Egyptians suffered the effects of darkness, we too can experience spiritual darkness when we turn away from God. This darkness can manifest as confusion, emptiness, or a lack of purpose. Therefore, it is crucial to remain rooted in God's word and to seek his light in all situations. Fourthly, the psalm encourages us to be agents of light in a dark world. Just as God sent darkness to Egypt, he calls us to shine his light into the dark corners of society. This means speaking out against injustice, showing compassion to those in need, and sharing the good news of the gospel. We are called to be beacons of hope, reflecting God's love and truth in a world that is often characterized by darkness and despair. Finally, we can learn from the Egyptians' stubbornness. We must be careful not to harden our hearts to God's prompting and resist the urge to prioritize our own desires over his will. Humility and a willingness to submit to God's authority are essential for experiencing his blessings and walking in his light.
prayer: Sovereign God, you command the darkness and it obeys. Forgive me for the times I have resisted your will and chosen my own way. Help me to recognize your sovereignty in all aspects of my life, even in the difficult times. Grant me a heart that is receptive to your word and a willingness to obey your commands. Shine your light into the dark corners of my life and illuminate the path you have for me. Use me as an instrument of your light in this world, to bring hope and healing to those in need. Help me not to harden my heart like Pharaoh, but to yield to your loving guidance. I offer you my obedience and trust, knowing that you are always faithful. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The use of 'they' might be a poetic device or reflecting a subtle personification of the darkness, as if it were an entity acting according to God's will. It emphasizes the totality of the darkness obeying, almost as if it were a collective force.
faqs.question: Q1: Why does the verse say 'they' (darkness) instead of 'it'?

faqs.answer: This verse illustrates God's wrath being manifested through natural phenomena. The darkness isn't random; it's a directed judgment demonstrating God's power and displeasure against Pharaoh's defiance.
faqs.question: Q2: How does this verse relate to the concept of God's wrath?

faqs.answer: The verse highlights the intrinsic authority and effectiveness of God's word. It's not merely informative but performative; God speaks, and reality conforms. It underscores his omnipotence in a tangible way.
faqs.question: Q3: What does this verse teach about the power of God's word?

faqs.answer: It means actively seeking to understand and obey God's commandments as revealed in scripture and through the guidance of the Holy Spirit. It's about aligning your choices with God's will.
faqs.question: Q4: How can I apply the idea of 'not rebelling against God's word' in my daily life?

faqs.answer: This verse contrasts with the concept of Jesus as the light. Where God previously used darkness as judgment, He now offers light through Jesus, signifying salvation and reconciliation rather than condemnation.
